Our Great Expectations report published 5 years ago. Looked into the career aspirations of 14–19-year-olds to ascertain how well informed or misunderstood they were about the realities of entering the workplace, plus the inclusion of employers within careers advice@balfourbeatty

Our report published five years ago this week, highlighted gender differences in expectations from young people.
Lack of access to careers advice was evident in the research which recommended that impartial access be made available, informed by the local labour market.

5 years ago, our research forecast the human health & social work sector would experience the most growth. Today 1/3 of all UK vacancies are in the sector. We've developed Step into Social Care to support people who have recently lost their jobs to transition into the sector.

5 years ago, we published Great Expectations to understand how a void of information is impacting young people's career decision making. Teens share their reasons for wanting to go to university, while the data revealed the growth of alternative route jobs and career advice gaps
Click for unique insights from our recent#engineeringand the green economy webinar industry guests', hear how companies, jobs and workplaces are evolving.http://ow.ly/HHtT50CA4xC

Five years ago, we asked teens to state their preferred future job, our respondents selected from a relatively narrow pool of available jobs. 
We called for employers to get much more involved in schools to inform and inspire young people about a far greater range of jobs.

It's been 5 years since we published our Great Expectations research. It revealed 68% of young people were planning to go to university, but according to @EMSI_UK, only 30% of jobs require a degree. We'll be looking back on our findings and recommendations to see what has changed
